importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was updated on this date, indicating the current status of Coca-Cola's rollout of cane sugar soda in the United States.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Coca-Cola announced the launch of the cane sugar soda in July 2025, with rollout beginning in late October 2025, aligning with Trump’s earlier advocacy.

keyTakeAways: Coca-Cola has begun selling a soda made with cane sugar instead of high-fructose corn syrup in the U.S., in response to a demand from President Donald Trump.
The switch is part of a broader trend toward healthier beverage options, despite health experts noting that sugary sodas—whether made with cane sugar or corn syrup—are not healthy.
This move follows President Trump's advocacy against high-fructose corn syrup, particularly promoted by his Health and Human Services Secretary, Robert F. Kennedy, Jr.
Coca-Cola already uses cane sugar in certain international markets and in select U.S. products like Simply lemonade and Gold Peak iced tea.

The launch comes at a time when Coca-Cola is expanding its range of sugar-free and healthier beverages, including Coca-Cola Zero Sugar, which saw a 14% global volume increase and boosted company shares by over 3%.

namedEntities.name: Coca-Cola
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Coca-Cola is central to the article, as it is the company launching a cane sugar soda in the U.S. in response to President Trump’s demand.

namedEntities.name: President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former U.S. President and political figure
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump publicly demanded that Coca-Cola use cane sugar instead of high-fructose corn syrup, prompting the company's decision to make the change.

namedEntities.name: Robert F. Kennedy, Jr.
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services under Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He has been a vocal critic of high-fructose corn syrup, influencing the policy and public discourse around food ingredients.

namedEntities.name: High-fructose corn syrup
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A common food additive and sweetener
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the ingredient that Coca-Cola previously used and that Trump and Kennedy Jr. have both criticized, making it a key point of controversy in the article.

namedEntities.name: Cane sugar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A natural sweetener derived from sugarcane
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the new sweetener Coca-Cola is adopting in the U.S. soda, replacing high-fructose corn syrup, as a result of political pressure and consumer demand.

namedEntities.name: Coca-Cola Zero Sugar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A sugar-free cola product by Coca-Cola
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It represents Coca-Cola’s broader shift toward healthier, sugar-free products, showing the company’s strategic expansion beyond sugary drinks.

namedEntities.name: Simply lemonade
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It already uses cane sugar in the U.S., indicating the company's existing use of cane sugar in other products.

namedEntities.name: Gold Peak iced tea
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It already uses cane sugar in the U.S., showing that cane sugar is already being used in select Coca-Cola products.

namedEntities.name: Costa canned coffee
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It already uses cane sugar in the U.S., reflecting Coca-Cola’s broader adoption of cane sugar in certain product lines.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Coca-Cola uses cane sugar in Mexico, showing international precedent for the sweetener’s use, which supports the U.S. rollout.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is part of Coca-Cola’s broader portfolio of healthier drink options, illustrating the company’s strategic shift toward wellness.

namedEntities.name: BodyArmor

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its relaunch signals Coca-Cola’s broader strategy of introducing healthier, sugar-free beverage alternatives.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Coca-Cola has begun rolling out a soda made with cane sugar instead of high-fructose corn syrup in the United States, in direct response to a public demand from President Donald Trump. The move follows advocacy by Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., who has long criticized high-fructose corn syrup. While health experts emphasize that sugary sodas—regardless of sweetener—are not healthy, this shift reflects Coca-Cola’s broader strategy toward healthier, sugar-free products, including the relaunch of BodyArmor and growth in sales of Coca-Cola Zero Sugar, which grew 14% globally. The company already uses cane sugar in international markets like Mexico and in select U.S. products such as Simply lemonade, Gold Peak iced tea, and Costa canned coffee, indicating a gradual transition across its product line.
title: Coca-Cola’s Trump-approved soda begins to roll out in the United States
